title: Most Test runs in a calendar year, full list: Jaiswal overtakes Sehwag with second-best India tally
description: Yashasvi Jaiswal ended 2024 with one of the best run-tallies by a Test opener in a calendar year, also setting a new India record.
author: Aadya Sharma

text: Yashasvi Jaiswal ended 2024 with one of the best run-tallies by a Test opener in a calendar year, also setting a new India record. Jaiswal, who is India’s top run-getter in the ongoing Border Gavaskar Trophy, scored 171 in Perth and hit 82 & 84 in Melbourne. His run-tally in 2024 now stands at 1,478 runs at 54.74: only Joe Root has scored more runs this year. His fighting 84 in the fourth innings at the MCG was cut short by a controversial caught-behind dismissal. Jaiswal’s run tally is the fourth-best for a Test opener in a calendar year, behind Graeme Smith (1,656 runs in 2008) as well as Michael Vaughan and Justin Langer (1,481 runs in 2002 and 2004 respectively). Jaiswal also hit 12 fifty-plus scores, the joint second-best by an opener in a calendar year, level with Sunil Gavaskar (1979) and Graeme Smith (2008), and bettered only by Virender Sehwag (13 in 2010). Jaiswal beat Sehwag’s 2008 tally of 1,462 runs to set a new record for an India opener in a calendar year. Interestingly, Jaiswal also has three ducks this year, the joint-third most by an Indian Test opener in a calendar year. The bulk of Jaiswal’s runs this year have come at home: 1,091 runs at 60.61, which is a record for any Test opener. He beat the 1990 record set by Graham Gooch, who scored 1,058 runs in England at 96.18, including his epic 333. Yashasvi Jaiswal ended 2024 with one of the best run-tallies by a Test opener in a calendar year, also setting a new India record.

Jaiswal, who is India’s top run-getter in the ongoing Border Gavaskar Trophy, scored 171 in Perth and hit 82 & 84 in Melbourne. His run-tally in 2024 now stands at 1,478 runs at 54.74: only Joe Root has scored more runs this year. His fighting 84 in the fourth innings at the MCG was cut short by a controversial caught-behind dismissal.

Jaiswal’s run tally is the fourth-best for a Test opener in a calendar year, behind Graeme Smith (1,656 runs in 2008) as well as Michael Vaughan and Justin Langer (1,481 runs in 2002 and 2004 respectively). Jaiswal also hit 12 fifty-plus scores, the joint second-best by an opener in a calendar year, level with Sunil Gavaskar (1979) and Graeme Smith (2008), and bettered only by Virender Sehwag (13 in 2010).

Jaiswal beat Sehwag’s 2008 tally of 1,462 runs to set a new record for an India opener in a calendar year. Interestingly, Jaiswal also has three ducks this year, the joint-third most by an Indian Test opener in a calendar year.

The bulk of Jaiswal’s runs this year have come at home: 1,091 runs at 60.61, which is a record for any Test opener. He beat the 1990 record set by Graham Gooch, who scored 1,058 runs in England at 96.18, including his epic 333.

Overall, it is the second-best tally by an India batter in a calendar year, only behind Sachin Tendulkar's 1,562 runs from 2010. Tendulkar hit seven Test centuries that year, a feat that hasn't been matched by an Indian yet.
